video.title: Think Like a Computer Science Professor
video.description:
See how to think like a computer science professor. You will observe Radu’s thought process as he codes a project for the first time. Many tutorials demonstrate how to build something that the instructor has already fully planned out beforehand. But in this video you learn what really goes into building a project from scratch. And he does it all without even referencing the Internet. 

Radu Mariescu-Istodor has a PhD in computer science. He teaches computer science at a university as well as on his YouTube channel.

🔗 Radu's channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/RaduMariescuIstodor
🔗 Radu's website: https://radufromfinland.com

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00:00) Intro / showcase  
⌨️ (00:01:32) Quick planning
⌨️ (00:03:25) Canvas project setup
⌨️ (00:09:21) Trying to remember how drawImage works :-))
⌨️ (00:18:58) Figured out I need to let it load first
⌨️ (00:20:29) Helper code for getting coordinates
⌨️ (00:22:27) Beginning procedural drawing
⌨️ (00:29:16) Normalizing the space for symmetrical drawing
⌨️ (00:48:32) Control point for head rotation
⌨️ (00:56:48) Slider for head x rotation
⌨️ (01:13:44) Rotating the head on X
⌨️ (01:17:27) Rotating the head on Y
⌨️ (01:28:14) Adding more control points
⌨️ (01:59:31) Drawing eyes
⌨️ (02:26:59) Styling the eyes
⌨️ (02:42:42) Drawing the beard
⌨️ (03:22:51) Drawing the nose
⌨️ (03:27:25) Spoiler (I never get the nose to look better)
⌨️ (03:31:35) Drawing hair
⌨️ (03:51:48) Skin, Neck & Body 
⌨️ (04:07:43) Drawing the clothes
⌨️ (04:24:15) Some fine-tuning
⌨️ (04:43:00) Drawing the ears
⌨️ (04:53:50) Polishing and commenting code
⌨️ (05:17:41) Camera setup
⌨️ (05:34:27) Image processing: Isolating blue pixels
⌨️ (05:49:36) Moving avatar with camera
⌨️ (05:55:59) Plan for day 2 (Important)
⌨️ (06:02:32) Code refactoring with OOP
⌨️ (06:15:43) Ditching the idea* above and sticking to point A
⌨️ (06:43:07) Linear algebra
⌨️ (06:52:20) Particle system
⌨️ (07:08:57) Constraints (segments)
⌨️ (08:00:50) Dynamic front hair skeleton 
⌨️ (08:17:30) Dynamic back hair skeleton
⌨️ (08:31:43) Sliders to control the mouth
⌨️ (08:45:09) Real-time face tracking 
⌨️ (09:42:58) Recognizing facial markers
⌨️ (10:03:58) Solving the 'fidgiting' problem by averaging
⌨️ (10:09:14) On averaging points
⌨️ (10:10:14) Side-points of mouth
⌨️ (10:11:56) Quick demo and quick planning
⌨️ (10:13:41) Working with pre-recorded video
⌨️ (10:24:03) Multi-input support in interface
⌨️ (10:57:40) Styling front hair
⌨️ (11:18:13) Styling back hair
⌨️ (11:35:18) Adding side hair
⌨️ (11:40:56) Debugging option
⌨️ (11:50:40) Shirt strings 
⌨️ (12:00:21) Extensive testing
⌨️ (12:01:34) Final touches
⌨️ (12:09:50) Trying to fix nose, then gave up (too tired & found some bug)
⌨️ (12:30:46) Final testing, writing instructions and last thoughts


--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

replies.author: OSKAR MAYER JP
replies.text: To be fair, while most people expected the money printing to cause inflation, most didn't expect it to get this bad. There was a series of black swan events that made it this bad. We thought vaccine was going to end COVID but it did not. We expected supply chain to return to normal, instead we got multiple waves, creating a labor shortage instead of unemployment, and then China lockdowns, and then war broke out in europe, the oil prices shot way up... those are all things most people last year using conventional wisdom wasn't expecting. To be honest, last year this time I was against having a third round of stimulus and was expecting a 4-5% inflation but one that last 5 or so years that slow burns through the increased money supply.

topLevelComment.author: Michael Walker
topLevelComment.text: Wow!  How do you keep those JavaScript functions in your head, to recall which functions you should call first such as whether the name of the function would be mouseDown, mouseClick, getImage, etc?  Sorry, I'm totally blind, so I only have the benefit of listening to the video, and not seeing what is visually shown on screen.

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: I often don't remember all and need to look them up. But this was recorded in the second half of the academic year so, after I've been teaching them several times, and they were fresh in memory. I didn't remember some things (like how to detect an event when dragging the sliders, instead of when releasing the sliders), so, I could have done some things better if I would have looked them up, but it was a nice experience like this.

topLevelComment.author: deecm22
topLevelComment.text: When would someone ever develop an avatar like this?  This does not seem to be a practical example.  This is similar to hello world and foo bar functions.  Why not do something more useful like closing a security hole.

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: @deecm22 I agree... My logic for doing these things is to keep things interesting. I think that those who write 'bad code' need some practice, and working on an interesting project should be more motivating.

replies.author: deecm22
replies.text: @Radu Mariescu-Istodor understood.  I would just point out that we have “bad code” in production environments all across the world that the younger generations will have to support and refactor. It is unlikely that they will be asked to create a talking avatar.  Most developers don’t know how to solve basic problems like cross site scripting.  This is a great tutorial in focused problem solving so there is value. Point taken however. I will take matters into my own hands and contribute using practical use cases.  Thank you for your effort and for the inspiration to do more.

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: I think I'll be using it to make some character animation in the future :-) or maybe some coding tutorial where the avatar is the one talking (just for fun). So, I find use for it... and the techniques inside here are quite general, they are useful in clustering applications, image processing and physics simulations, so, even if this application is not very useful to you, it may contain something that is... hard to say.

topLevelComment.author: SeverSFSs
topLevelComment.text:
Would love to see more of these style videos and in different cs fields. Ive been trying to get into game development and I cant even begin to explain how frustrating it is learning everything from tutorials with step by step instructions and having to translate one aspect of a completely different project into your own. It doesnt allow you to learn any concepts or how they could be used in different scenarios.

Seeing the mistakes, watching the thought process, hearing the different terms or explanations, it all gives sooo much more insight into how to actually think about solving unique/dynamic problems.

topLevelComment.author: dogwater
topLevelComment.text:
suggestion: could you PLEASE make another tutorial that explains how to make a discord chatbot/AI? Ive tried tons of your tutorials, including the one that explains how to make a bot talk like your favorite character, and i think the script may be seriously outdated or something. Ive followed everything right, it never works. there is always some sort of error i can never improve, and i dont know why. i was wondering if there was some way you could address this, or remake a video. ive retried everything on the tutorial 5 times. failed, same unsolvable problem, every time. most of the tutorials are seriously outdated, honestly. (the tutorials on making discord chat bots. most of them are outdated, or dont work.) so i just feel if you make another tutorial on it, itd be really helpful or even boost your channel. 

please. i seriously need a chatbot tutorial

topLevelComment.author: Sachin Bhujel
topLevelComment.text: It's a crucial skill to have in the computer science world. There's many different coding languages out there. First, start with the basics, which are HTML and CSS. Then you can soon move on to more complex languages, but are still relatively easy to get a hang of, like Python and Java.

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: I'm actually 'lucky' to have started with C. Because now I can switch to other high-level languages quite easily (almost nothing surprises me anymore). But on the other hand, many of my colleagues didn't get attracted by C... so they never got interested in coding. I think starting with something light weight is not a bad idea :-)

replies.author: Dan Green
replies.text: If the goal is to learn programming and computer science, start with C. If you start with Python then you'll end up working backwards eventually to learn what you would have already learned by starting with C.

replies.author: LOMZO GAMING
replies.text: start somewhere

replies.author: Calculus Horse
replies.text: Start with C, you’ll learn a lot. I mean it’s literally the first programming language taught in Harvard.

replies.author: charles0
replies.text: @Marui Infantry I second that opinion. Also Python is far more accessible than Java and I would personally recommend starting with Python.
